facts.text: Appellant Jagmohan Singh convicted under section 302 IPC for murder of Chhotey Singh and sentenced to death by Sessions Judge Shahjahanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Jagmohan Singh has been companyvinced under section 302-IPC for the murder of one Chhotey Singh and sentenced to death by the learned Sessions Judge, Shahjahanpur.

facts.text: Conviction and death sentence confirmed by Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction and the sentence are companyfirmed by the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court limited to the question of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: on the appellant companying to this Court by special leave, special leave was granted limited to the question of sentence only.

facts.text: Six or seven years before the present offence, Shivraj Singh, father of Jagbir Singh (cousin of appellant), was murdered.

anchor.surface_text: The short facts of the case are that some six or seven years before the present offence, one Shivraj Singh, father of Jagbir Singh, a companysin of the appellant, was murdered.

facts.text: Chhotey Singh charged for murder of Shivraj Singh but acquitted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased Chhotey Singh was charged for that murder but was eventually acquitted by the High Court.

facts.text: Ill-feeling between Chhotey Singh and appellant Jagmohan Singh and Jagbir Singh as result of Shivraj Singh's murder.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of that murder, there was ill-feeling between Chhotey Singh, on the one hand, and the appellant and Jagbir Singh, on the other.

facts.text: Appellant and Jagbir Singh were minors at time of Shivraj Singh's murder but had grown up by time of Chhotey Singh's murder.

anchor.surface_text: Both of them were minors at the time of the murder of Shivraj Singh. But by number they had grown up and it is plain from the evidence...

facts.text: Chhotey Singh murdered on September 10, 1969 at about 5.00 P.M.

anchor.surface_text: Chhotey Singh was murdered on September 10, 1969 at about 5.00 P.M.

facts.text: Day before murder, quarrel between Jagmohan Singh, Jagbir Singh and Chhotey Singh over right to irrigate fields, settled without incident.

anchor.surface_text: A day earlier, there was a quarrel between Jagmohan Singh and Jagbir Singh, on the one hand, and Chhotey Singh, on the other, on the question of a right to irrigate their fields.

facts.text: Appellant armed with country made pistol and Jagbir Singh with lathi concealed in bajra field.

anchor.surface_text: Next day, however, the appellant armed with a companyntry made pistol and Jagbir Singh armed with a lathi companycealed themselves in a bajra field

facts.text: Appellant and Jagbir emerged from bajra field as Chhotey Singh passed by to his field for fetching fodder.

anchor.surface_text: and emerged from the same as Chhotey Singh passed by to go to his field for fetching fodder.

facts.text: Appellant asked Chhotey Singh to stop to settle matter once for all.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant asked Chhotey Singh to stop so that the matter between them companyld be settled once for all.

facts.text: Chhotey Singh tried to run away, chased by appellant and shot in the back.

anchor.surface_text: Naturally Chhotey Singh tried to run away but he was chased by the appellant and shot in the back.

facts.text: Chhotey Singh fell down after running some distance and died.

anchor.surface_text: Chhotey Singh fell down after running some distance and died. That is how the murder was companymitted.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held appellant deserved extreme penalty based on facts and circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts and circumstances of the case, the learned Ses- sions Judge held that the appellant deserved the extreme penalty.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court confirmed death sentence, observed no extenuating circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, while companyfirming the death sentence, observed that there were numberextenuating circumstances and the sentence of death...

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal is Criminal Appeal No. 173 of 1971 from Allahabad High Court Criminal Appeal No. 1229 of 1970 and Reference No. 96 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 173 of 1971. Appeal, by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 26, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court...

facts.text: Appellant armed himself with gun and lay in wait for victim without immediate provocation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had armed himself with a gun and was lying in wait for the victim to pass. There was numberimmediate cause.

facts.text: Murder motivated by ill-feelings nurtured for years and premeditated.

anchor.surface_text: The murder was entirely motivated by ill-feelings nurtured for years. The offence was pre- meditated.

facts.text: Supreme Court not inclined to interfere with sentence imposed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, number inclined to interfere with the sentence imposed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Jagmohan Singh has been convicted under section 302-IPC for the murder of one Chhotey Singh and sentenced to death by the learned Sessions Judge, Shahjahanpur.

issues.text: Whether this Court should interfere with the sentence imposed by the Trial Court and confirmed by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, while confirming the death sentence, observed that there were no extenuating circumstances and the sentence of death awarded to the appellant was just and proper. The question is whether this Court should interfere with the sentence.

issues.text: Whether the death sentence for murder is unconstitutional as it puts an end to fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(a) to (g) and fails the test of reasonableness and public interest

anchor.surface_text: In the first place he contended, the death sentence puts an end to all fundamental rights guaranteed under clauses a to g of sub-clause 1 of Article 19 and, therefore, the law with regard to capital sentence is unreasonable and not in the interest of the general public.

issues.text: Whether section 302 IPC involves excessive delegation of legislative function by providing judicial discretion without standards or policy for choosing between death and life imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, he contended, the discretion invested in the Judges to impose capital punishment is not based on any standards or policy required by the Legislature for imposing capital punishment in preference to imprisonment for, life.

issues.text: Whether the uncontrolled and unguided discretion of judges to impose death or life imprisonment under section 302 IPC violates Article 14

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, he contended, the uncontrolled and unguided discretion in the Judges to impose capital punishment or imprisonment for life is hit by Article 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the procedure under the Criminal Procedure Code for sentencing in murder cases violates Article 21 as there is no specific procedure for considering sentencing factors after conviction

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was contended that the provisions of the law do not provide a procedure for trial of factors and circumstances crucial for making the choice between the capital penalty and imprisonment for life.

holdings.text: This Court is not inclined to interfere with the death sentence imposed by the High Court and confirmed after concurrent exercise of discretion by trial court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it can hardly be said that the High Court did number exercise its discretion properly. We are, therefore, number inclined to interfere with the sentence imposed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No disregard of sentencing principles; premeditated murder with lying in wait, no immediate provocation, motivated by long-nurtured ill-feelings; follows precedent in Ram Narain v State of UP.

holdings.text: Section 302 IPC prescribing death for murder passes the test of reasonableness under Article 19 and is in public interest.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of affairs, we are number prepared to companyclude that capital punishment, as such, is either unreasonable or number in the public interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes right to life basic to Art 19; applies G Row test considering nature of right, purpose, urgency, disproportion; Constitution recognizes death penalty (Art 72,134,21); Law Commission recommends retention given Indian conditions.

holdings.text: Providing judicial discretion under section 302 IPC to choose between death and life imprisonment does not amount to excessive delegation of legislative function.

anchor.surface_text: We think there is numbermerit in this submission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Criminal law policy fixes maximum for worst cases, leaves wide discretion to judges due to infinite variety of circumstances; supported by Halsbury, Royal Commission, Ratanlal, IPC structure.

holdings.text: Judicial discretion to impose death or life imprisonment under section 302 IPC does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: we do number find any merit in this companytention also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cases differ in facts/circumstances; no discrimination; Art 14 not for judicial discretion per Budhan Choudhry; revision by higher courts prevents arbitrariness.

holdings.text: The procedure under CrPC for imposing death sentence in murder cases satisfies Article 21.

anchor.surface_text: We are number impressed by this argument also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed procedure from magistrate to SC appeal; all relevant facts/mitigating circumstances before court during trial; examination u/s342, addresses on sentence; s309(2) mandates sentence according to law.

precedents.citation: Ram Narain and others v. The State of U.P.  1

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by this Court in Ram Narain and others v. The State of U.P.  1  this Court normally does not interfere with the discretion exercised by the High Court on the question of sentence unless the High Court has disregarded recognised principles in imposing the sentence and there has been a failure of justice. It. cannot be said on the facts of this case that there has been any breach of the principles governing the matter of sentence.

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Supreme Court normally does not interfere with the discretion exercised by the High Court on the question of sentence unless the High Court has disregarded recognised principles in imposing the sentence and there has been a failure of justice.

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. G. Row 1

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it would be proper to recall the observations of Patanjali Sastri, CJ in State of Madras v. G. Row 1  at page 607 It is important in this context to bear in mind that the test of reasonableness, wherever prescribed, should be applied to each individual statute impugned, and not abstract standard. or- general pattern, of reasonableness can be laid down as applicable to all cases.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. G. Row
precedents.cited_proposition: Test of reasonableness applied to each individual statute impugned; nature of right, purpose of restrictions, extent of evil, disproportion, prevailing conditions all enter into judicial verdict.

precedents.citation: Furman v. State of Georgia  Nos. 69-5003, 619-5030 and 69- 5031 decided on June 29, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The arguments advanced by Mr. Garg against death penalty per se were practically similar to those which were addressed recently to the Supreme Court of America in the case of Furman v. State of Georgia  Nos. 69-5003, 619-5030 and 69- 5031 decided on June 29, 1972  and obtained the assent of two Judges, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall.

precedents.cited_proposition: Arguments that death penalty violates Eighth Amendment as cruel and unusual punishment.
precedents.cited_holding: Death sentences set aside by majority, but only two judges held capital punishment unconstitutional per se.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, to be noted in the above case of Furman v. State of Georgia that though the learned Judges by a majority of 5 to 4 set aside the sentences of death with which they were concerned, it was only Brennan and Marshall, JJ. who were prepared to outlaw capital punishment on the ground that it was an anachronism, degrading to human dignity and unnecessary in modern life.

precedents.cited_proposition: Majority set aside specific death sentences but did not outlaw capital punishment entirely.

anchor.surface_text: It has, however, to be remembered that, in the language of F ankurter, J. in Snowden v. Hughes, the Constitution does not assure uniformity of decisions or immunity from merely erroneous action, whether by the Courts or the executive agencies of a State.

precedents.cited_proposition: Constitution does not assure uniformity of decisions or immunity from merely erroneous action by courts or executive.

anchor.surface_text: American experience is not different. In some of the States murder and rape were punishable with death. But that was not the only punishment. The, Law gave the Jury discretion in capital sentencing, and the question arose recently before the Supreme Court of America in McGauthn v. California 1  whether in tile absence of any standards for deciding when the accused should be sentenced to death or to life imprisonment the provision of law which gives the discretion to the Jury was constitutional.

precedents.cited_proposition: Jury discretion in capital sentencing without standards is constitutional given infinite variety of cases.
precedents.cited_holding: Untrammeled discretion of jury in capital cases not offensive to Constitution.

precedents.citation: Budhan Choudhry and others v. The State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: It has been pointed out by this Court in Budhan Choudhry and others v. The State of Bihar   Art. 14 can hardly be invoked in matters of judicial, discretion. This Court observed at page 1054 It has, however, to be remembered that, in the language of F ankurter, J. in Snowden v. Hughes,

precedents.case_name: Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 14 cannot be invoked in matters of judicial discretion; no assurance of uniformity of decisions.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the Punjab High Court has held that considerable delay in the disposal of a case may be a factor in awarding lesser punishment. See Municipal Committee v. Baisakhi Ram 1 . The policy of the law in giving a very wide discretion in the matter of punishment to the Judge has its origin in the impossibility of laying down standards.

precedents.cited_proposition: Considerable delay in disposal of case may be a factor in awarding lesser punishment.
